column2: Those who are willing to listen to fair words, may learn from this ensample, that he who seeks another's ill often brings the evil upon himself.
column3: Those who are willing to listen to fair words, may learn from this ensample, that he who seeks another's ill often brings the evil upon himself.

column2: As I have told you before, of this adventure the Bretons made the Lay of Equitan, the lady whom he loved, and of their end.
column3: As I have told you before, of this adventure the Bretons made the Lay of Equitan, the lady whom he loved, and of their end.

column2: XII
column3: twelve

column2: THE LAY OF MILON
column3: THE LAY OF MILON

column2: He who would tell divers tales must know how to vary the tune.
column3: He who would tell divers tales must know how to vary the tune.

column2: To win the favour of any, he must speak to the understanding of all.
column3: To win the favour of any, he must speak to the understanding of all.

column2: I purpose in this place to show you the story of Milon, and--since few words are best--I will set out the adventure as briefly as I may.
column3: I purpose in this place to show you the story of Milon, and-since few words are best-I will set out the adventure as briefly as I may.

column2: Milon was born in South Wales.
column3: Milon was born in South Wales.

column2: So great was his prowess that from the day he was dubbed knight there was no champion who could stand before him in the lists.
column3: So great was his prowess that from the day he was dubbed knight there was no champion who could stand before him in the lists.

column2: He was a passing fair knight, open and brave, courteous to his friends, and stern to his foes.
column3: He was a passing fair knight, open and brave, courteous to his friends, and stern to his foes.

column2: Men praised his name in whatever realm they talked of gallant deeds--Ireland, Norway, and Wales, yea, from Jutland even to Albania.
column3: Men praised his name in whatever realm they talked of gallant deeds-Ireland, Norway, and Wales, yea, from Jutland even to Albania.

column2: Since he was praised by the frank, he was therefore envied of the mean.
column3: Since he was praised by the frank, he was therefore envied of the mean.

column2: Nevertheless, by reason of his skill with the spear, he was counted a very worshipful knight, and was honourably entreated by many a prince in divers lands.
column3: Nevertheless, by reason of his skill with the spear, he was counted a very worshipful knight, and was honourably entreated by many a prince in divers lands.

column2: In Milon's own realm there lived a lord whose name has gone from mind.
column3: In Milon's own realm there lived a lord whose name has gone from mind.

column2: With this baron dwelt his daughter, a passing fair and gracious damsel.
column3: With this baron dwelt his daughter, a passing fair and gracious damsel.

column2: Much talk had this maiden heard of Milon's knightly deeds, so that she began to set her thoughts upon him, because of the good men spoke of him.
column3: Much talk had this maiden heard of Milon's knightly deeds, so that she began to set her thoughts upon him, because of the good men spoke of him.

column2: She sent him a message by a sure hand, saying that if her love was to his mind, sweetly would it be to her heart.
column3: She sent him a message by a sure hand, saying that if her love was to his mind, sweetly would it be to her heart.

column2: Milon rejoiced greatly when he knew this thing.
column3: Milon rejoiced greatly when he knew this thing.

column2: He thanked the lady for her words, giving her love again in return for her own, and swearing that he would never depart therefrom any day of his days.
column3: He thanked the lady for her words, giving her love again in return for her own, and swearing that he would never depart therefrom any day of his days.

column2: Beyond this courteous answer Milon bestowed on the messenger costly gifts, and made him promises that were richer still.
column3: Beyond this courteous answer Milon bestowed on the messenger costly gifts, and made him promises that were richer still.

column2: Friend, said he, "of your charity I pray you that I may have speech with my friend, in such a fashion that none shall know of our meeting. Carry her this, my golden ring.
column3: Friend, said he, "of your charity I pray you that I may have speech with my friend, in such a fashion that none shall know of our meeting. Carry her this, my golden ring.

column2: Tell her, on my part, that so she pleases she shall come to me, or, if it be her better pleasure, I will go to her."
column3: Tell her, on my part, that so she pleases she shall come to me, or, if it be her better pleasure, I will go to her."

column2: The messenger bade farewell, and returned to his lady.
column3: The messenger bade farewell, and returned to his lady.

column2: He placed the ring in her hand, saying that he had done her will, as he was bidden to do.
column3: He placed the ring in her hand, saying that he had done her will, as he was bidden to do.

column2: Right joyous was the damsel to know that Milon's love was tender as her own.
column3: Right joyous was the damsel to know that Milon's love was tender as her own.

column2: She required her friend to come for speech within the private garden of her house, where she was wont to take her delight.
column3: She required her friend to come for speech within the private garden of her house, where she was wont to take her delight.

column2: Milon came at her commandment.
column3: Milon came at her commandment.

column2: He came so often, and so dearly she loved him, that in the end she gave him all that maid may give.
column3: He came so often, and so dearly she loved him, that in the end she gave him all that maid may give.

column2: When the damsel perceived how it was with her, she sent messages to her friend, telling him of her case, and making great sorrow.
column3: When the damsel perceived how it was with her, she sent messages to her friend, telling him of her case, and making great sorrow.

column2: I have lost my father and all his wealth, said the lady, "for when he hears of this matter he will make of me an example.
column3: I have lost my father and all his wealth, said the lady, "for when he hears of this matter he will make of me an example.

column2: Either I shall be tormented with the sword, or else he will sell me as a slave in a far country."
column3: Either I shall be tormented with the sword, or else he will sell me as a slave in a far country."

column2: (For such was the usage of our fathers in the days of this tale).
column3: (For such was the usage of our fathers in the days of this tale).

column2: Milon grieved sorely, and made answer that he would do the thing the damsel thought most seemly to be done.
column3: Milon grieved sorely, and made answer that he would do the thing the damsel thought most seemly to be done.

column2: When the child is born, replied the lady, "you must carry him forthwith to my sister.
column3: When the child is born, replied the lady, "you must carry him forthwith to my sister.

column2: She is a rich dame, pitiful and good, and is wedded to a lord of Northumberland.
column3: She is a rich dame, pitiful and good, and is wedded to a lord of Northumberland.

column2: You will send messages with the babe--both in writing and by speech--that the little innocent is her sister's child.
column3: You will send messages with the babe-both in writing and by speech-that the little innocent is her sister's child.

column2: Whether it be a boy or girl his mother will have suffered much because of him, and for her sister's sake you will pray her to cherish the babe.
column3: Whether it be a boy or girl his mother will have suffered much because of him, and for her sister's sake you will pray her to cherish the babe.

column2: Beyond this I shall set your signet by a lace about his neck, and write letters wherein shall be made plain the name of his sire, and the sad story of his mother.
column3: Beyond this I shall set your signet by a lace about his neck, and write letters wherein shall be made plain the name of his sire, and the sad story of his mother.

column2: When he shall have grown tall, and of an age to understand these matters, his aunt will give him your ring, and rehearse to him the letter.
column3: When he shall have grown tall, and of an age to understand these matters, his aunt will give him your ring, and rehearse to him the letter.

column2: If this be done, perchance the orphan will not be fatherless all his days."
column3: If this be done, perchance the orphan will not be fatherless all his days."

column2: Milon approved the counsel of the lady, and when her time had come she was brought to bed of a boy.
column3: Milon approved the counsel of the lady, and when her time had come she was brought to bed of a boy.

column2: The old nurse who tended her mistress was privy to the damsel's inmost mind.
column3: The old nurse who tended her mistress was privy to the damsel's inmost mind.

column2: So warily she went to work, so cunning was she in gloss and concealment, that none within the palace knew that there was aught to hide.
column3: So warily she went to work, so cunning was she in gloss and concealment, that none within the palace knew that there was aught to hide.

column2: The damsel looked upon her boy, and saw that he was very fair.
column3: The damsel looked upon her boy, and saw that he was very fair.

column2: She laced the ring about his neck, and set the letter that it were death to find, within a silken chatelaine.
column3: She laced the ring about his neck, and set the letter that it were death to find, within a silken chatelaine.

column2: The child was then placed in his cradle, swathed close in white linen.
column3: The child was then placed in his cradle, swathed close in white linen.

column2: A pillow of feathers was put beneath his head, and over all was laid a warm coverlet, wadded with fur.
column3: A pillow of feathers was put beneath his head, and over all was laid a warm coverlet, wadded with fur.

column2: In this fashion the ancient nurse gave the babe to his father, who awaited him within the garden.
column3: In this fashion the ancient nurse gave the babe to his father, who awaited him within the garden.

column2: Milon commended the child to his men, charging them to carry him loyally, by such towns as they knew, to that lady beyond the Humber.
column3: Milon commended the child to his men, charging them to carry him loyally, by such towns as they knew, to that lady beyond the Humber.

column2: The servitors set forth, bearing the infant with them.
column3: The servitors set forth, bearing the infant with them.

column2: Seven times a day they reposed them in their journey, so that the women might nourish the babe, and bathe and tend him duly.
column3: Seven times a day they reposed them in their journey, so that the women might nourish the babe, and bathe and tend him duly.

column2: They served their lord so faithfully, keeping such watch upon the way, that at the last they won to the lady to whom they were bidden.
column3: They served their lord so faithfully, keeping such watch upon the way, that at the last they won to the lady to whom they were bidden.

column2: The lady received them courteously, as became her breeding.
column3: The lady received them courteously, as became her breeding.

column2: She broke the seal of the letter, and when she was assured of what was therein, marvellously she cherished the infant.
column3: She broke the seal of the letter, and when she was assured of what was therein, marvellously she cherished the infant.

column2: These having bestowed the boy in accordance with their lord's commandment, returned to their own land.
column3: These having bestowed the boy in accordance with their lord's commandment, returned to their own land.

column2: Milon went forth from his realm to serve beyond the seas for guerdon. His friend remained within her house and was granted by her father in marriage to a right rich baron of that country.
column3: Milon went forth from his realm to serve beyond the seas for guerdon. His friend remained within her house and was granted by her father in marriage to a right rich baron of that country.

column2: Though this baron was a worthy knight, justly esteemed of all his fellows, the damsel was grieved beyond measure when she knew her father's will.
column3: Though this baron was a worthy knight, justly esteemed of all his fellows, the damsel was grieved beyond measure when she knew her father's will.

column2: She called to mind the past, and regretted that Milon had gone from the country, since he would have helped her in her need.
column3: She called to mind the past, and regretted that Milon had gone from the country, since he would have helped her in her need.

column2: Alas! said the lady, "what shall I do?
column3: Alas! said the lady, "what shall I do?

column2: I doubt that I am lost, for my lord will find that his bride is not a maid.
column3: I doubt that I am lost, for my lord will find that his bride is not a maid.

column2: If this becomes known they will make me a bondwoman for all my days.
column3: If this becomes known they will make me a bondwoman for all my days.

column2: Would that my friend were here to free me from this coil.
column3: Would that my friend were here to free me from this coil.

column2: It were good for me to die rather than to live, but by no means can I escape from their hands.
column3: It were good for me to die rather than to live, but by no means can I escape from their hands.

column2: They have set warders about me, men, old and young, whom they call my chamberlains, contemners of love, who delight themselves in sadness. But endure it I must, for, alas, I know not how to die."
column3: They have set warders about me, men, old and young, whom they call my chamberlains, contemners of love, who delight themselves in sadness. But endure it I must, for, alas, I know not how to die."

column2: So on the appointed day the lady was wedded to the baron, and her husband took her to dwell with him in his fief.
column3: So on the appointed day the lady was wedded to the baron, and her husband took her to dwell with him in his fief.

column2: When Milon returned to his own country he was right heavy and sorrowful to learn of this marriage.
column3: When Milon returned to his own country he was right heavy and sorrowful to learn of this marriage.

column2: He lamented his wretched case, but in this he found comfort, that he was not far from the realm where the lady abode whom so tenderly he loved.
column3: He lamented his wretched case, but in this he found comfort, that he was not far from the realm where the lady abode whom so tenderly he loved.

column2: Milon commenced to think within himself how best he might send letters to the damsel that he was come again to his home, yet so that none should have knowledge thereof.
column3: Milon commenced to think within himself how best he might send letters to the damsel that he was come again to his home, yet so that none should have knowledge thereof.

column2: He wrote a letter, and sealed it with his seal.
column3: He wrote a letter, and sealed it with his seal.

column2: This message he made fast to the neck, and hid within the plumage of a swan that was long his, and was greatly to his heart.
column3: This message he made fast to the neck, and hid within the plumage of a swan that was long his, and was greatly to his heart.

column2: He bade his squire to come, and made him his messenger.
column3: He bade his squire to come, and made him his messenger.

column2: Change thy raiment swiftly, said he, "and hasten to the castle of my friend.
column3: Change thy raiment swiftly, said he, "and hasten to the castle of my friend.

column2: Take with thee my swan, and see that none, neither servant nor handmaid, delivers the bird to my lady, save thyself alone."
column3: Take with thee my swan, and see that none, neither servant nor handmaid, delivers the bird to my lady, save thyself alone."

column2: The squire did according to his lord's commandment.
column3: The squire did according to his lord's commandment.

column2: He made him ready quickly, and went forth, bearing the swan with him.
column3: He made him ready quickly, and went forth, bearing the swan with him.

column2: He went by the nearest road, and passing through the streets of the city, came before the portal of the castle.
column3: He went by the nearest road, and passing through the streets of the city, came before the portal of the castle.

column2: In answer to his summons the porter drew near.
column3: In answer to his summons the porter drew near.

column2: Friend, said he, "hearken to me.
column3: Friend, said he, "hearken to me.

column2: I am of Caerleon, and a fowler by craft.
column3: I am of Caerleon, and a fowler by craft.

column2: Within my nets I have snared the most marvellous swan in the world.
column3: Within my nets I have snared the most marvellous swan in the world.

column2: This wondrous bird I would bestow forthwith upon your lady, but perforce I must offer her the gift with my own hand."
column3: This wondrous bird I would bestow forthwith upon your lady, but perforce I must offer her the gift with my own hand."

column2: Friend, replied the porter, "fowlers are not always welcomed of ladies.
column3: Friend, replied the porter, "fowlers are not always welcomed of ladies.

column2: If you come with me I will bring you where I may know whether it pleases my lady to have speech with you and to receive your gift."
column3: If you come with me I will bring you where I may know whether it pleases my lady to have speech with you and to receive your gift."

column2: The porter entered in the hall, where he found none but two lords seated at a great table, playing chess for their delight.
column3: The porter entered in the hall, where he found none but two lords seated at a great table, playing chess for their delight.

column2: He swiftly returned on his steps, and the fowler with him, so furtively withal that the lords were not disturbed at their game, nor perceived aught of the matter.
column3: He swiftly returned on his steps, and the fowler with him, so furtively withal that the lords were not disturbed at their game, nor perceived aught of the matter.

column2: They went therefore to the chamber of the lady.
column3: They went therefore to the chamber of the lady.

column2: In answer to their call the door was opened to them by a maiden, who led them before her dame.
column3: In answer to their call the door was opened to them by a maiden, who led them before her dame.

column2: When the swan was proffered to the lady it pleased her to receive the gift.
column3: When the swan was proffered to the lady it pleased her to receive the gift.

column2: She summoned a varlet of her household and gave the bird to his charge, commanding him to keep it safely, and to see that it ate enough and to spare.
column3: She summoned a varlet of her household and gave the bird to his charge, commanding him to keep it safely, and to see that it ate enough and to spare.

column2: Lady, said the servitor, "I will do your bidding.
column3: Lady, said the servitor, "I will do your bidding.

column2: We shall never receive from any fowler on earth such another bird as this.
column3: We shall never receive from any fowler on earth such another bird as this.

column2: The swan is fit to serve at a royal table, for the bird is plump as he is fair."
column3: The swan is fit to serve at a royal table, for the bird is plump as he is fair."

column2: The varlet put the swan in his lady's hands.
column3: The varlet put the swan in his lady's hands.

column2: She took the bird kindly, and smoothing his head and neck, felt the letter that was hidden beneath its feathers.
column3: She took the bird kindly, and smoothing his head and neck, felt the letter that was hidden beneath its feathers.

column2: The blood pricked in her veins, for well she knew that the writing was sent her by her friend.
column3: The blood pricked in her veins, for well she knew that the writing was sent her by her friend.

column2: She caused the fowler to be given of her bounty, and bade the men to go forth from her chamber.
column3: She caused the fowler to be given of her bounty, and bade the men to go forth from her chamber.

column2: When they had parted the lady called a maiden to her aid. She broke the seal, and unfastening the letter, came upon the name of Milon at the head.
column3: When they had parted the lady called a maiden to her aid. She broke the seal, and unfastening the letter, came upon the name of Milon at the head.

column2: She kissed the name a hundred times through her tears.
column3: She kissed the name a hundred times through her tears.

column2: When she might read the writing she learned of the great pain and dolour that her lover suffered by day and by night.
column3: When she might read the writing she learned of the great pain and dolour that her lover suffered by day and by night.

column2: In you--he wrote--is all my pleasure, and in your white hands it lies to heal me or to slay.
column3: In you-he wrote-is all my pleasure, and in your white hands it lies to heal me or to slay.

column2: Strive to find a plan by which we may speak as friend to friend, if you would have me live.
column3: Strive to find a plan by which we may speak as friend to friend, if you would have me live.

column2: The knight prayed her in his letter to send him an answer by means of the swan.
column3: The knight prayed her in his letter to send him an answer by means of the swan.

column2: If the bird were well guarded, and kept without provand for three days, he would of a surety fly back to the place from whence he came, with any message that the lady might lace about his neck.
column3: If the bird were well guarded, and kept without provand for three days, he would of a surety fly back to the place from whence he came, with any message that the lady might lace about his neck.

column2: When the damsel had considered the writing, and understood what was put therein, she commanded that her bird should be tended carefully, and given plenteously to eat and to drink.
column3: When the damsel had considered the writing, and understood what was put therein, she commanded that her bird should be tended carefully, and given plenteously to eat and to drink.

column2: She held him for a month within her chamber, but this was less from choice, than for the craft that was necessary to obtain the ink and parchment requisite for her writing.
column3: She held him for a month within her chamber, but this was less from choice, than for the craft that was necessary to obtain the ink and parchment requisite for her writing.

column2: At the end she wrote a letter according to her heart, and sealed it with her ring.
column3: At the end she wrote a letter according to her heart, and sealed it with her ring.

column2: The lady caused the swan to fast for three full days; then having concealed the message about his neck, let him take his flight.
column3: The lady caused the swan to fast for three full days; then having concealed the message about his neck, let him take his flight.

column2: The bird was all anhungered for food, and remembering well the home from which he drew, he returned thither as quickly as his wings might bear him.
column3: The bird was all anhungered for food, and remembering well the home from which he drew, he returned thither as quickly as his wings might bear him.

column2: He knew again his town, and his master's house, and descended to the ground at Milon's very feet.
column3: He knew again his town, and his master's house, and descended to the ground at Milon's very feet.

column2: Milon rejoiced greatly when he marked his own.
column3: Milon rejoiced greatly when he marked his own.

column2: He caught the bird by his wings, and crying for his steward, bade him give the swan to eat.
column3: He caught the bird by his wings, and crying for his steward, bade him give the swan to eat.

column2: The knight removed the missive from the messenger's neck.
column3: The knight removed the missive from the messenger's neck.

column2: He glanced from head to head of the letter, seeking the means that he hoped to find, and the salutation he so tenderly wished.
column3: He glanced from head to head of the letter, seeking the means that he hoped to find, and the salutation he so tenderly wished.

column2: Sweet to his heart was the writing, for the lady wrote that without him there was no joy in her life, and since it was his desire to hear by the swan, it would be her pleasure also.
column3: Sweet to his heart was the writing, for the lady wrote that without him there was no joy in her life, and since it was his desire to hear by the swan, it would be her pleasure also.

column2: For twenty years the swan was made the messenger of these two lovers, who might never win together.
column3: For twenty years the swan was made the messenger of these two lovers, who might never win together.

column2: There was no speech between them, save that carried by the bird.
column3: There was no speech between them, save that carried by the bird.

column2: They caused the swan to fast for three days, and then sent him on his errand.
column3: They caused the swan to fast for three days, and then sent him on his errand.

column2: He to whom the letter came, saw to it that the messenger was fed to heart's desire.
column3: He to whom the letter came, saw to it that the messenger was fed to heart's desire.

column2: Many a time the swan went upon his journey, for however strictly the lady was held of her husband, there was none who had suspicion of a bird.
column3: Many a time the swan went upon his journey, for however strictly the lady was held of her husband, there was none who had suspicion of a bird.

column2: The dame beyond the Humber nourished and tended the boy committed to her charge with the greatest care.
column3: The dame beyond the Humber nourished and tended the boy committed to her charge with the greatest care.

column2: When he was come to a fitting age she made him to be knighted of her lord, for goodly and serviceable was the lad.
column3: When he was come to a fitting age she made him to be knighted of her lord, for goodly and serviceable was the lad.

column2: On the same day the aunt read over to him the letter, and put in his hand the ring.
column3: On the same day the aunt read over to him the letter, and put in his hand the ring.

column2: She told him the name of his mother, and his father's story.
column3: She told him the name of his mother, and his father's story.

column2: In all the world there was no worthier knight, nor a more chivalrous and gallant gentleman.
column3: In all the world there was no worthier knight, nor a more chivalrous and gallant gentleman.

column2: The lad hearkened diligently to the lady's tale.
column3: The lad hearkened diligently to the lady's tale.

column2: He rejoiced greatly to hear of his father's prowess, and was proud beyond measure of his renown.
column3: He rejoiced greatly to hear of his father's prowess, and was proud beyond measure of his renown.

column2: He considered within himself, saying to his own heart, that much should be required of his father's son, and that he would not be worthy of his blood if he did not endeavour to merit his name.
column3: He considered within himself, saying to his own heart, that much should be required of his father's son, and that he would not be worthy of his blood if he did not endeavour to merit his name.

column2: He determined therefore that he would leave his country, and seek adventure as a knight errant, beyond the sea.
column3: He determined therefore that he would leave his country, and seek adventure as a knight errant, beyond the sea.

column2: The varlet delayed no longer than the evening.
column3: The varlet delayed no longer than the evening.

column2: On the morrow he bade farewell to his aunt, who having warned and admonished him for his good, gave him largely of her wealth, to bring him on his way.
column3: On the morrow he bade farewell to his aunt, who having warned and admonished him for his good, gave him largely of her wealth, to bring him on his way.

column2: He rode to Southampton, that he might find a ship equipped for sea, and so came to Barfleur.
column3: He rode to Southampton, that he might find a ship equipped for sea, and so came to Barfleur.

column2: Without any tarrying the lad went straight to Brittany, where he spent his money and himself in feasts and in tourneys.
column3: Without any tarrying the lad went straight to Brittany, where he spent his money and himself in feasts and in tourneys.

column2: The rich men of the land were glad of his friendship, for there was none who bore himself better in the press with spear or with sword.
column3: The rich men of the land were glad of his friendship, for there was none who bore himself better in the press with spear or with sword.

column2: What he took from the rich he bestowed on such knights as were poor and luckless.
column3: What he took from the rich he bestowed on such knights as were poor and luckless.

column2: These loved him greatly, since he gained largely and spent freely, granting of his wealth to all.
column3: These loved him greatly, since he gained largely and spent freely, granting of his wealth to all.

column2: Wherever this knight sojourned in the realm he bore away the prize.
column3: Wherever this knight sojourned in the realm he bore away the prize.

column2: So debonair was he and chivalrous that his fame and praise crossed the water, and were noised abroad in his own land.
column3: So debonair was he and chivalrous that his fame and praise crossed the water, and were noised abroad in his own land.

column2: Folk told how a certain knight from beyond the Humber, who had passed the sea in quest of wealth and honour, had so done, that by reason of his prowess, his liberality, and his modesty, men called him the Knight Peerless, since they did not know his name.
column3: Folk told how a certain knight from beyond the Humber, who had passed the sea in quest of wealth and honour, had so done, that by reason of his prowess, his liberality, and his modesty, men called him the Knight Peerless, since they did not know his name.

column2: This praise of the good knight, and of his deeds, came to be heard of Milon.
column3: This praise of the good knight, and of his deeds, came to be heard of Milon.

column2: Very dolent was he and sorely troubled that so young a knight should be esteemed above his fathers.
column3: Very dolent was he and sorely troubled that so young a knight should be esteemed above his fathers.

column2: He marvelled greatly that the stout spears of the past had not put on their harness and broken a lance for their ancient honour.
column3: He marvelled greatly that the stout spears of the past had not put on their harness and broken a lance for their ancient honour.

column2: One thing he determined, that he would cross the sea without delay, so that he might joust with the dansellon, and abate his pride.
column3: One thing he determined, that he would cross the sea without delay, so that he might joust with the dansellon, and abate his pride.

column2: In wrath and anger he purposed to fight, to beat his adversary from the saddle, and bring him at last to shame.
column3: In wrath and anger he purposed to fight, to beat his adversary from the saddle, and bring him at last to shame.

column2: After this was ended he would seek his son, of whom he had heard nothing, since he had gone from his aunt's castle.
column3: After this was ended he would seek his son, of whom he had heard nothing, since he had gone from his aunt's castle.

column2: Milon caused his friend to know of his wishes.
column3: Milon caused his friend to know of his wishes.

column2: He opened out to her all his thought, and craved her permission to depart.
column3: He opened out to her all his thought, and craved her permission to depart.

column2: This letter he sent by the swan, commending the bird to her care.
column3: This letter he sent by the swan, commending the bird to her care.

column2: When the lady heard of her lover's purpose, she thanked him for his courtesy, for greatly was his counsel to her mind.
column3: When the lady heard of her lover's purpose, she thanked him for his courtesy, for greatly was his counsel to her mind.

column2: She approved his desire to quit the realm for the sake of his honour, and far from putting let and hindrance in his path, trusted that in the end he would bring again her son.
column3: She approved his desire to quit the realm for the sake of his honour, and far from putting let and hindrance in his path, trusted that in the end he would bring again her son.

column2: Since Milon was assured of his friend's goodwill, he arrayed himself richly, and crossing the sea to Normandy, came afterwards into the land of the Bretons.
column3: Since Milon was assured of his friend's goodwill, he arrayed himself richly, and crossing the sea to Normandy, came afterwards into the land of the Bretons.

column2: There he sought the friendship of the lords of that realm, and fared to all the tournaments of which he might hear.
column3: There he sought the friendship of the lords of that realm, and fared to all the tournaments of which he might hear.

column2: Milon bore himself proudly, and gave graciously of his wealth, as though he were receiving a gift. He sojourned till the winter was past in that land, he, and a brave company of knights whom he held in his house with him.
column3: Milon bore himself proudly, and gave graciously of his wealth, as though he were receiving a gift. He sojourned till the winter was past in that land, he, and a brave company of knights whom he held in his house with him.

column2: When Easter had come, and the season that men give to tourneys and wars and the righting of their private wrongs, Milon considered how he could meet with the knight whom men called Peerless.
column3: When Easter had come, and the season that men give to tourneys and wars and the righting of their private wrongs, Milon considered how he could meet with the knight whom men called Peerless.

column2: At that time a tournament was proclaimed to be held at Mont St. Michel.
column3: At that time a tournament was proclaimed to be held at Mont st Michel.

column2: Many a Norman and Breton rode to the game; knights of Flanders and of France were there in plenty, but few fared from England.
column3: Many a Norman and Breton rode to the game; knights of Flanders and of France were there in plenty, but few fared from England.

column2: Milon drew to the lists amongst the first.
column3: Milon drew to the lists amongst the first.

column2: He inquired diligently of the young champion, and all men were ready to tell from whence he came, and of his harness, and of the blazon on his shield.
column3: He inquired diligently of the young champion, and all men were ready to tell from whence he came, and of his harness, and of the blazon on his shield.

column2: At length the knight appeared in the lists and Milon looked upon the adversary he so greatly desired to see.
column3: At length the knight appeared in the lists and Milon looked upon the adversary he so greatly desired to see.

column2: Now in this tournament a knight could joust with that lord who was set over against him, or he could seek to break a lance with his chosen foe.
column3: Now in this tournament a knight could joust with that lord who was set over against him, or he could seek to break a lance with his chosen foe.

column2: A player must gain or lose, and he might find himself opposed either by his comrade or his enemy.
column3: A player must gain or lose, and he might find himself opposed either by his comrade or his enemy.

column2: Milon did well and worshipfully in the press, and was praised of many that day.
column3: Milon did well and worshipfully in the press, and was praised of many that day.

column2: But the Knight Peerless carried the cry from all his fellows, for none might stand before him, nor rival him in skill and address.
column3: But the Knight Peerless carried the cry from all his fellows, for none might stand before him, nor rival him in skill and address.

column2: Milon observed him curiously.
column3: Milon observed him curiously.

column2: The lad struck so heavily, he thrust home so shrewdly, that Milon's hatred changed to envy as he watched.
column3: The lad struck so heavily, he thrust home so shrewdly, that Milon's hatred changed to envy as he watched.

column2: Very comely showed the varlet, and much to Milon's mind.
column3: Very comely showed the varlet, and much to Milon's mind.

column2: The older knight set himself over against the champion, and they met together in the centre of the field.
column3: The older knight set himself over against the champion, and they met together in the centre of the field.

column2: Milon struck his adversary so fiercely, that the lance splintered in his gauntlet; but the young knight kept his seat without even losing a stirrup.
column3: Milon struck his adversary so fiercely, that the lance splintered in his gauntlet; but the young knight kept his seat without even losing a stirrup.

column2: In return his spear was aimed with such cunning that he bore his antagonist to the ground.
column3: In return his spear was aimed with such cunning that he bore his antagonist to the ground.

column2: Milon lay upon the earth bareheaded, for his helmet was unlaced in the shock.
column3: Milon lay upon the earth bareheaded, for his helmet was unlaced in the shock.

column2: His hair and beard showed white to all, and the varlet was heavy to look on him whom he had overthrown.
column3: His hair and beard showed white to all, and the varlet was heavy to look on him whom he had overthrown.

column2: He caught the destrier by the bridle, and led him before the stricken man.
column3: He caught the destrier by the bridle, and led him before the stricken man.

column2: Sir, said he, "I pray you to get upon your horse.
column3: Sir, said he, "I pray you to get upon your horse.

column2: I am right grieved and vexed that I should have done this wrong.
column3: I am right grieved and vexed that I should have done this wrong.

column2: Believe me that it was wrought unwittingly."
column3: Believe me that it was wrought unwittingly."

column2: Milon sprang upon his steed.
column3: Milon sprang upon his steed.

column2: He approved the courtesy of his adversary, and looking upon the hand that held his bridle, he knew again his ring.
column3: He approved the courtesy of his adversary, and looking upon the hand that held his bridle, he knew again his ring.

column2: He made inquiry of the lad.
column3: He made inquiry of the lad.

column2: Friend, said he, "hearken to me.
column3: Friend, said he, "hearken to me.

column2: Tell me now the name of thy sire. How art thou called; who is thy mother?
column3: Tell me now the name of thy sire. How art thou called; who is thy mother?

column2: I have seen much, and gone to and fro about the world.
column3: I have seen much, and gone to and fro about the world.

column2: All my life I have journeyed from realm to realm, by reason of tourneys and quarrels and princes' wars, yet never once by any knight have I been borne from my horse.
column3: All my life I have journeyed from realm to realm, by reason of tourneys and quarrels and princes' wars, yet never once by any knight have I been borne from my horse.

column2: This day I am overthrown by a boy, and yet I cannot help but love thee."
column3: This day I am overthrown by a boy, and yet I cannot help but love thee."

column2: The varlet answered, "I know little of my father.
column3: The varlet answered, "I know little of my father.

column2: I understand that his name is Milon, and that he was a knight of Wales.
column3: I understand that his name is Milon, and that he was a knight of Wales.

column2: He loved the daughter of a rich man, and was loved again.
column3: He loved the daughter of a rich man, and was loved again.

column2: My mother bore me in secret, and caused me to be carried to Northumberland, where I was taught and tended.
column3: My mother bore me in secret, and caused me to be carried to Northumberland, where I was taught and tended.

column2: An old aunt was at the costs of my nourishing.
column3: An old aunt was at the costs of my nourishing.

column2: She kept me at her side, till of all her gifts she gave me horse and arms, and sent me here, where I have remained.
column3: She kept me at her side, till of all her gifts she gave me horse and arms, and sent me here, where I have remained.

column2: In hope and wish I purpose to cross the sea, and return to my own realm.
column3: In hope and wish I purpose to cross the sea, and return to my own realm.

column2: There I would seek out my father, and learn how it stands between him and my mother.
column3: There I would seek out my father, and learn how it stands between him and my mother.

column2: I will show him my golden ring, and I will tell him of such privy matters that he may not deny our kinship, but must love me as a son, and ever hold me dear."
column3: I will show him my golden ring, and I will tell him of such privy matters that he may not deny our kinship, but must love me as a son, and ever hold me dear."

column2: When Milon heard these words he could endure them no further.
column3: When Milon heard these words he could endure them no further.

column2: He got him swiftly from his horse, and taking the lad by the fringe of his hauberk, he cried, "Praise be to God, for now am I healed.
column3: He got him swiftly from his horse, and taking the lad by the fringe of his hauberk, he cried, "Praise be to God, for now am I healed.

column2: Fair friend, by my faith thou art my very son, for whom I came forth from my own land, and have sought through all this realm."
column3: Fair friend, by my faith thou art my very son, for whom I came forth from my own land, and have sought through all this realm."

column2: The varlet climbed from the saddle, and stood upon his feet.
column3: The varlet climbed from the saddle, and stood upon his feet.

column2: Father and son kissed each other tenderly, with many comfortable words.
column3: Father and son kissed each other tenderly, with many comfortable words.

column2: Their love was fair to see, and those who looked upon their meeting, wept for joy and pity.
column3: Their love was fair to see, and those who looked upon their meeting, wept for joy and pity.

column2: Milon and his son departed from the tournament so soon as it came to an end, for the knight desired greatly to speak to the varlet at leisure, and to open before him all his mind.
column3: Milon and his son departed from the tournament so soon as it came to an end, for the knight desired greatly to speak to the varlet at leisure, and to open before him all his mind.

column2: They rode to their hostel, and with the knights of their fellowship, passed the hours in mirth and revelry.
column3: They rode to their hostel, and with the knights of their fellowship, passed the hours in mirth and revelry.

column2: Milon spoke to the lad of his mother.
column3: Milon spoke to the lad of his mother.

column2: He told him of their long love, and how she was given by her father in marriage to a baron of his realm.
column3: He told him of their long love, and how she was given by her father in marriage to a baron of his realm.

column2: He rehearsed the years of separation, accepted by both with a good heart, and of the messenger who carried letters between them, when there was none they dared to trust in, save only the swan.
column3: He rehearsed the years of separation, accepted by both with a good heart, and of the messenger who carried letters between them, when there was none they dared to trust in, save only the swan.

column2: The son made answer,
column3: The son made answer,

column2: In faith, fair father, let us return to our own land.	In faith, fair father, let us return to our own land.
column3: true

column2: There I will slay this husband, and you shall yet be my mother's lord."
column3: There I will slay this husband, and you shall yet be my mother's lord."

column2: This being accorded between them, on the morrow they made them ready for the journey, and bidding farewell to their friends, set forth for Wales.
column3: This being accorded between them, on the morrow they made them ready for the journey, and bidding farewell to their friends, set forth for Wales.

column2: They embarked in a propitious hour, for a fair wind carried the ship right swiftly to its haven.
column3: They embarked in a propitious hour, for a fair wind carried the ship right swiftly to its haven.

column2: They had not ridden far upon their road, when they met a certain squire of the lady's household on his way to Brittany, bearing letters to Milon.
column3: They had not ridden far upon their road, when they met a certain squire of the lady's household on his way to Brittany, bearing letters to Milon.

column2: His task was done long before sundown in chancing on the knight.
column3: His task was done long before sundown in chancing on the knight.

column2: He gave over the sealed writing with which he was charged, praying the knight to hasten to his friend without any tarrying, since her husband was in his grave.
column3: He gave over the sealed writing with which he was charged, praying the knight to hasten to his friend without any tarrying, since her husband was in his grave.

column2: Milon rejoiced greatly when he knew this thing.
column3: Milon rejoiced greatly when he knew this thing.

column2: He showed the message to his son, and pressed forward without pause or rest.
column3: He showed the message to his son, and pressed forward without pause or rest.

column2: They made such speed, that at the end they came to the castle where the lady had her lodging.
column3: They made such speed, that at the end they came to the castle where the lady had her lodging.

column2: Light of heart was she when she clasped again her child. These two fond lovers sought neither countenance of their kin, nor counsel of any man.
column3: Light of heart was she when she clasped again her child. These two fond lovers sought neither countenance of their kin, nor counsel of any man.

column2: Their son handselled them together, and gave the mother to his sire.
column3: Their son handselled them together, and gave the mother to his sire.

column2: From the day they were wed they dwelt in wealth and in sweetness to the end of their lives.
column3: From the day they were wed they dwelt in wealth and in sweetness to the end of their lives.

column2: Of their love and content the minstrel wrought this Lay.
column3: Of their love and content the minstrel wrought this Lay.

column2: I, also, who have set it down in writing, have won guerdon enough just by telling over the tale.
column3: I, also, who have set it down in writing, have won guerdon enough just by telling over the tale.

column2: XIII
column3: thirteen

column2: THE LAY OF YONEC
column3: THE LAY OF y o n e c

column2: Since I have commenced I would not leave any of these Lays untold. The stories that I know I would tell you forthwith.
column3: Since I have commenced I would not leave any of these Lays untold. The stories that I know I would tell you forthwith.

column2: My hope is now to rehearse to you the story of Yonec, the son of Eudemarec, his mother's first born child.
column3: My hope is now to rehearse to you the story of Yonec, the son of Eudemarec, his mother's first born child.
